title: Beef industry mourns loss of Sir Graham McCamley
text:
The Australian beef industry is mourning the passing of a "giant" modern-day pioneer who revolutionised the cattle game.

Sir Graham McCamley died peacefully in Yeppoon, central Queensland, at the weekend.

He was 93.

Sir Graham lived an extraordinary life, founding the Cattlemen's Union of Australia and helping to develop and promote the Brahman breed, and his influence stretched across agriculture, politics and rural Australia.

AgForce president Shane McCarthy led the tributes for the Australian cattle icon, describing Sir Graham's leadership and integrity as his biggest legacy.

"They don't make them like Sir Graham anymore," he said.

" In the footsteps of giants we follow, and he was one of those people. "

Sir Graham McCamley was the first president of the Cattlemen's Union of Australia. (ABC: Jacquie Mackay)

Mr McCarthy said Sir Graham was instrumental in the formation of the Cattlemen's Union in 1975 and was one of the founding fathers of the Brahman breed as it is today.

He said during the beef depression of the 1970s, Sir Graham made sure graziers had someone speaking on their behalf.

"He was the inaugural president of the Cattleman's Union, which in those days played a very strong, pivotal role and he set the standard for other people to follow," he said.

"His influence on the beef industry was incomparable, and the industry mourns his passing and passes on their condolences to his family."

Brett Coombs was family friends with Sir Graham before working together.

He said the cattle baron was an innovator and industry changer.

"He was always thinking outside the box," Mr Coombs said.

"Living in the bush, we get floods, we get droughts and Graham just never gave up.

"I just tip my hat to Graham."

Michelle Landry and Sir Graham McCamley. (Supplied: Michelle Landry)

Member for Capricornia Michelle Landry said Sir Graham was a legendary figure in the Australian cattle industry.

"From building one of Queensland's most respected cattle empires and championing the Brahman breed, to serving as the founding president of the Cattlemen's Union of Australia, Sir Graham's lifelong dedication to agriculture and his community was truly remarkable," she said.

State MP for Keppel Nigel Hutton said Sir Graham was a true central Queensland legend.

"Sir Graham helped build the Australian cattle industry and his impact extends across the globe," he said.

Rockhampton Regional Council Mayor Tony Williams said Sir Graham was "a giant of our region and our nation".

"His was a life well-lived that has left a legacy that will last generations to come," he said.

McCamley cattle empire

Sir Graham was born on August 24, 1932, and grew up on a property near Dululu, west of Rockhampton.

Soon after marrying his wife, Shirley, the couple purchased Tartrus Station, west of Marlborough, in central Queensland, which was the start of the McCamley cattle empire, which grew to six cattle properties.

Sir Graham McCamley in the saleyards at Tartrus. (ABC Rural)

He and Lady Shirley were true leaders in the industry. They used the first computer in the state at the University of Queensland and held field days that drew unprecedented numbers to their property, near Marlborough.

"People didn't know what we were talking about [with] all this performance testing, fertility testing and weight performance," Sir Graham told the ABC in 2013.

"At the '71 field day, we were expecting two to three hundred people at the very most, but 1,000 people turned up."

In 2010, Lady Shirley died in an ultralight plan crash at Tartrus.

Sir Graham sold the iconic Tartrus cattle station in 2013 before retiring to Yeppoon.

The sale marked the end of an era for the family on the property where they had lived for nearly 60 years.

In 1981, Sir Graham was appointed a Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) in the Queen's Birthday honours list, for his contribution to the beef industry.

In 1986, Sir Graham was knighted for his outstanding contributions to the beef industry.

Sir Graham had three children and seven grandchildren.

title: The toad busters determined to take back a tropical island from its invaders
text:
On a tropical island off the Queensland coast, locals love to hate one of Australia's most infamous pests.

For more than 50 years, revellers have flocked to Magnetic Island for its cane toad races — placing their bets on which toad will hop the fastest out of the arena.

Toad handler Paul Gilligan said the competition, which raises money for a local surf lifesaving club, regularly sees crowds of more than 100 cheering on a winner.

"It's just something so unique that you don't see anywhere else," he said.

Paul Gilligan gets the toads ready for their weekly race. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

Sitting just 8 kilometres from Townsville, the island has a plentiful local talent pool to choose from — toads can be found in its parks, waterways and national park areas, as they can across much of northern Australia.

But one group of dedicated locals — the Maggie Toad Busters — are taking a different approach to dealing with the local toad population.

The group estimates they have gathered about 80 kilograms of tadpoles from waterways. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

Project co-leader Peter Illidge said the group was on an eradication mission, aiming to put a severe dent in the island's toad population over the next three years, with a $16,394 grant from the Queensland government's Gambling Community Benefit Fund.

"We've got a bunch of toad busters out there. The community has been doing this for a long time but we're bringing everybody together," he said.

" We are an island, so there's hope we could eradicate them. "

Bruce Holden and Peter Illidge have taken up 'toad busting' around the island. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

March of the toads

Cane toads were first introduced to North Queensland in the 1930s to control sugar cane beetles, but the species quickly became a widespread pest and is now found across Queensland, New South Wales, the Northern Territory and Western Australia.

This toad, named 'Toadzilla' was found in North Queensland in 2023. (Supplied: Queensland Museum)

Professor Ross Alford from James Cook University said the region's islands were no exception to their march across northern Australia, commonly hitchhiking to places like Magnetic Island in vehicles and cargo.

"There's so much vehicle traffic by ferries that it would be really surprising if they hadn't accidentally been carried over there by people," he said.

Cane toads breed rapidly. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

Euthanasia of cane toads is permitted in Australia, with several humane methods outlined by the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water.

Magnetic Island toad buster, Bruce Hobby said the group had laid 30 traps in local creeks, collecting and euthanasing about 80 kilograms of tadpoles over the past few months, as well as about 480 adult toads.

Magnetic Island is known as a habitat for koalas and turtles. (Supplied: Lawrence Scheele)

"Australia's wildlife is so unique and special, and to see it affected by what is essentially an invader of our country is sad," he said.

"There is a lot of them, they eat a lot, and they out-compete most other animals."

The toad busters are hoping to work with Townsville City Council to install bins at the island's parks, so members of the public can leave toads for the 'busters' to collect and destroy, to better protect the island's native species.

The group uses government funding to purchase plastic traps for tadpoles. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

Local action worthwhile

Busting toads is no small task, with the country infested by more than 200 million of the amphibians.

Environmental group Watergum's annual national toad busting event this year saw more than 2,000 people pitch in to remove 199,231 cane toads in 84 locations across Australia.

Cars and goods are transported to Magnetic Island via ferry. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

Professor Alford said although eradication was unlikely, localised community efforts to drive down numbers could be effective.

"On a more local scale, particularly on things like islands, you can trap them, collect them and reduce numbers that way," he said.

"By reducing their numbers you can reduce their impact on all the other animals they affect."

Magnetic Island toad busters have laid 30 traps in local creeks. (ABC North Qld: Meghan Dansie)

On Magnetic Island, Mr Illidge said the toad busters would continue their efforts over the next three years in the hope of ridding the island of the invasive species.

"We may not eradicate all the toads, but we'll definitely reduce their numbers to a point where they're not making such a big impact," he said.

"It would be nice to see no toads on the island — that's a dream."

title: Djokovic quits players body he co-founded over transparency concerns
text:
Novak Djokovic says he is stepping away from the Professional Tennis Players Association (PTPA), which he co-founded, citing concerns over transparency and governance within the organisation.

In a post on X, Djokovic wrote the decision was also driven by how his voice and image had been represented.

Djokovic launched the PTPA alongside Vasek Pospisil in 2020 with the aim of strengthening player representation within the sport.

"I am proud of the vision that Vasek and I shared when founding the PTPA, giving players a stronger, independent voice," Djokovic wrote.

"But it has become clear that my values and approach are no longer aligned with the current direction of the organisation."

In March, the PTPA launched legal action against tennis' governing organisations, including the ATP, WTA, International Tennis Federation and the International Tennis Integrity Agency.

The PTPA accused the organisations of anti-competitive practices and failing to safeguard player welfare.

Organisers of the four grand slam events were added to the case in September.

Djokovic, a 24-time major singles champion, said at the time he did not agree with all elements of the lawsuit, while both the ATP and WTA strongly rejected the allegations.

The PTPA said in November that it was close to a deal with Tennis Australia, which is currently preparing for the Australian Open.

The Australian Open begins in Melbourne on January 18.

Reuters

title: Live: Smith runs out of lives as Labuschagne gets shock breakthrough
text:
Joe Root batted brilliantly as wickets fell around him in the morning session on day two. (Getty Images)

An interesting first session in the books, highlighted by a wonderful, wonderful century from Joe Root.

The score for the session is 3-125, but I reckon England has squandered a chance to really get itself in the driver's seat.

Harry Brook started it by throwing away a century before Jamie Smith played one of the legitimately dumbest shots I've ever seen in Test cricket to give Marnus of all people a wicket.

Both men needed the application of Root, who has played a virtually chanceless knock out there.

"I've said it before, once he ticked off the hundred in Australia, he'll be the greatest player outside of Bradman, statistically," Darren Lehmann said on ABC Radio.

"He'll break all the records, he'll beat Tendulkar, he'll make more hundreds than anyone else and it'll take a lot of catching because he's quite fit."

Australia will be buoyed by having a new batter out there, particularly with the new ball just a couple of overs away after the break.

If they can pry Root out with it, then they'll like their chances of keeping England under 400, which would be a major win because this looks like a 450-500 pitch.

title: Live: Oil prices rebound after US strikes on Venezuela, ASX flat
text:
Shares in WiseTech Global are down 3.5% heading into the afternoon, after the regulator weighed in on competition concerns raised one of the firm's acquisitions.

This isn't entirely new news — on New Year's Eve, WiseTech released a statement to the ASX saying it had "voluntarily agreed" to sell Expedient Software, a subsidiary of BluJay Solutions, which WiseTech had acquired as part of a bigger deal in August 2025.

Last week, Wisetech said Expedient "formed a small and immaterial component of the business operations of E2open Parent Holdings" and was not part of the "investment rationale" behind its acquisition, noting it employed fewer than than 30 staff and "generates annual revenue of less than 0.4% of WiseTech's FY26 revenue guidance".

Today, the ACCC spelled out its side of the negotiations — saying WiseTech completed the acquisition before the regulator had finished evaluating competition implications.

"While WiseTech informed the ACCC about the acquisition, WiseTech completed the acquisition before the ACCC conducted its review and could reach a decision, despite being aware of the significant concerns being raised," ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb said.

The ACCC said the court-enforceable undertaking for WiseTech to sell Expedient "addresses the competition concerns identified by the ACCC in its investigation, by restoring Expedient as an independent competitor to WiseTech".

"The ACCC received significant concerns from users of logistics software during the investigation and was concerned that the acquisition could lead to higher prices or lower quality services," Ms Cass-Gottlieb said.

Last week, WiseTech chief executive Zubin Appoo said the firm maintained that its ownership of Expedient "does not lessen competition in the Australian market" but that the firm had agreed to sell it off and said there would be no material financial impact from the proposed divestment.

title: Residents in WA city warn of e-scooter dangers ahead of contract decision
text:
E-scooters are more popular than ever across Australia, but Geraldton resident Stuart Wise will never ride one again.

Mr Wise was riding a rental e-scooter to his local shops in the regional city about 400 kilometres north of Perth last month when he was struck by a car and seriously injured after he failed to see oncoming traffic.

He broke his leg in three places and required knee surgery.

He is urging people not to ride them.

"Just don't get on them. It's as simple as that. They're dangerous," Mr Wise said.

"You're virtually driving a car with no protection around you."

Mr Wise says he would not ride an e-scooter again after he broke his leg in three places. (ABC News: Piper Duffy)

Less than three weeks after Mr Wise's accident, another Geraldton man died after falling from a rental scooter on Christmas Eve, becoming the eighth person to die in an e-scooter-related incident in WA in 2025.

The tragedy has added to pressure on the local council to reconsider its contract with hire company, Beam Mobility, which will be up for renewal at the end of this month.

The e-scooters have proved popular with both residents and visitors. (ABC News: Bransen Gibson )

Calls for stronger enforcement

President of the Champion Bay Surf Life Saving Club, Peter Nelson, said he has witnessed a lot of "near misses" between riders and pedestrians on the Geraldton foreshore footpath.

While Mr Nelson said he was not against the rental scheme, he said there should be better control measures enforced.

"If people were more responsible with them, then it wouldn't be such an issue," he said.

Peter Nelson says he has witnessed many near misses involving e-scooters along the Geraldton foreshore. (ABC News: Claire Moodie)

"A lot of the time, it's younger people that are using them, and they don't have the same understanding of what the consequences can be."

Unlike privately owned scooters, Beam's e-scooters have "slow zones" where speeds are automatically reduced in high-pedestrian areas.

However, Mr Nelson wants even lower speed limits along the pathway, especially at peak times, including on Sunday mornings when up to 160 Nippers are running around.

A woman riding an e-scooter in Geraldton without a helmet. (ABC News: Bransen Gibson )

In June last year, former City of Greater Geraldton councillor Aaron Horsman put a motion for the hireable devices to be suspended until better safety precautions were in place.

"In the long term I don't think the pros outweigh the cons in regard to safety and whether they can be policed to a safe level," he said.

"Every day at the moment I see people without helmets riding [e-scooters] everywhere, yesterday I saw two double-dinking, no helmets, definitely under the age of 16."

Mr Horsman says there have been enough warning signs to warrant the council to not renew Beam's contract. (ABC News: Claire Moodie)

WA police said they will always immediately impound e-rideables that are being illegally operated and are collaborating with partner agencies and the state government to deliver state-wide education-focused operations.

Mr Horsman said councillors were warned by police that they would not have the resources to monitor the e-scooters before the scheme was approved in 2023.

"When we made the decision two years ago to vote for this scooter programme, we were given information that there was going to be problems from police," he said.

"Problems with them being able to police them and basically they didn't have the resources."

But unlike the Shire of Augusta-Margaret River, which knocked back a similar hire program due to safety reasons, Geraldton gave Beam the green light.

There is growing community concern about people riding e-scooters without helmets. (ABC News: Bransen Gibson)

Safety concerns

The mode of transport has recently been under scrutiny as a parliamentary inquiry into e-rideable safety revealed WA recorded a horror year for e-rideable-related fatalities in 2025.

The committee noted there were more e-scooter-related deaths in WA in 2025 than the previous three years combined.

The inquiry found that although limitations in data collection made it difficult to quantify the impact, there were unanimous reports from medical professionals that e-rideable injuries and fatalities were increasing.

Figures from St John WA showed they attended 539 e-scooter incidents in 2024, up from 453 in 2023.

As of the end of May 2025, they had already attended 328 incidents.

Accessible transport

A Beam Mobility spokesperson said the e-scooters had become a "valued part of Geraldton's transport mix".

A Beam Mobility spokesperson says the rental scheme allows people to have better access to places they might not otherwise be able to get to. (ABC News: Bransen Gibson )

"Since launching in Geraldton in September 2022, Beam's e-scooters have been embraced by the community, with close to 1 million kilometres travelled … over 99.9 per cent of trips start and end safely without incident," they said.

"They help connect people more easily with public transport and reach destinations they might not otherwise be able to go to."

In a statement, Beam said safety was its top priority, with its e-scooters including automatic speed limits and app reaction tests to deter drink driving.

It also pointed to its "Beam Safety ambassadors" patrolling high-traffic areas and a three-strikes policy where drivers face suspension for poor riding and parking offences.

Local resident, Lauren Harrington, said she would miss the scooters if they were banned because other public transport options in Geraldton were limited.

"I think for tourism as well, for people that don't bring cars, want to get around but don't want to walk. It's a really fun thing, " she said.

"I would be sad to see them go."

Local member for Geraldton, Kirrilee Warr, said the e-scooters benefited the community when used correctly, but said they were also risky.

Kirrilee Warr says the e-scooters work well when used appropriately. (ABC News: Piper Duffy)

"When used well and appropriately, [e-scooters] do form part of a transport mix for our community to get around," she said.

"There's been a call for increased penalties through that [parliamentary] inquiry, so we're certainly calling on the state government to start implementing those recommendations so we don't see a repeat of what we've seen in 2025."

title: League president reported to AFL over 'gender weirdness' alleged comments
text:
Kyneton Women's Football Club (KWFC) is considering legal action after AFL Victoria blocked its entry in a new league, leaving it "in limbo" and nowhere to play in 2026.

The Kyneton Women's Wedge-Tailed Eagles — which have said they champion diversity and inclusion — broke away from Kyneton Football Netball Club (KFNC) in 2024 following claims of disrespect and inequitable treatment. KFNC denies these claims and has maintained it has always been as inclusive as possible.

Kyneton was rejected by three competitions to play in 2025, including the Riddell District Football League (RDFNL), where it played as part of the Tigers in 2024.

Why Kyneton's women's side left their club Kyneton Football and Netball Club's women's team decided to break away from the club in the wake of what players describe as a "horrible, volatile environment".

The Central Victorian Football League (CVFL) then accepted its application with unanimous approval for the 2026 season, but AFL Victoria stepped in after an appeal made by the RDFNL.

There were many factors considered by the appeal board, including long-term sustainability of the club, participation impact on established pathways at other existing clubs and uncertainty around adequate facilities.

Weeks later, the president of the RDNFL, Brenton Knott, is alleged to have made comments in a leaked message to a supporter that the situation was "not about footy, it's about grooming and gender weirdness".

The message has been reported to the AFL integrity unit by Kyneton, which has called for a review of it. It was alleged to be sent via social media in response to a post on a public forum which was discussing KWFC's application to join the CVFL.

"You need to look at the other side. They don't deserve anything — you're advocating that any team that's not happy breaks away," the alleged message from Knott, which has been seen by the ABC, read.

"How is that manageable by the AFL? If you look at the principals (sic) in this — it's not about footy, it's about grooming and gender weirdness.

"You follow local footy so you need to see AFL Vic and RDFNL aren't the bad ones here."

In a response statement, KWFC said the club was deeply disturbed by the message, which was now public.

"Which uses harmful and offensive language in relation to gender diversity and inclusion in football," the statement by KWFC read.

"Inclusion is not a threat to football; it strengthens it."

Kyneton Women's Football Club is considering legal action after AFL Victoria blocked it from playing in the Central District Football League for the 2026 season. (Supplied: Ties Urie)

Knott, RDNFL and AFL Victoria have all been contacted for comment. The Daily Mail reported Knott to have denied the claims: "The comments attributed to me shouldn't have been. I am exploring legal advice moving forward."

Last year, AFL Victoria did a review of the circumstances that led to KFNC's women's side breaking away to form their own entity, including their claims of a lack of support from the league.

Those findings have not been released, and KWFC has called for the full review to be released to the club and general public.

The club is now preparing to go to the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal to seek a review and overturn AFL Victoria's appeal to not let them play in the CVFL for the 2026 season.

Meanwhile, the Kyneton Tigers did not field a women's team in 2025 following the mass women's team departure, but are set to return to the RDNFL in 2026 following the appointment of Lisa Borg as senior coach.

Peta Turnbull, a 24-year-old player for KWFC, said the group has been confused since leaving the Tigers as to why they have found it so hard to be accepted into a league.

Kyneton Women's Football Club players don't have a league to play in in 2026. (Supplied: Sophie McLeod)

She said that while the alleged comments by Knott were hard to read, they gave her some potential reasoning for what was going on.

"I'm so disgusted (by the alleged comments), but I feel so validated in that there is something deeper, bigger going on. It's not just about, I don't know, us not having a great application, (but) something else is going on behind closed doors," Turnbull told ABC Sport.

Player and president of KWFC, Natalie Korinfsky, added that the club wanted the RDNFL president's alleged comments investigated by the AFL, as she believed it was evidence of his prejudice, which may have influenced the appeal board, given his position of power.

"We're deeply concerned that there has been some bias, and if that was the kind of rhetoric that was going around the board at that time, you know, no wonder our applications never got through to the stage where they were successful," Korinfsky said.

Turnbull added playing football has helped her socially, mentally and physically and given her life a lot of stability, which has contributed to the application rejections hitting hard.

She said it feels like the club is being made an example of after speaking out against inequities within long-existing football systems.

"Every time we get hit back, it's just like another punch to the guts … it really frustrates me, there's been so much advancement in terms of women and what we can do now and what we have compared to earlier on (especially regarding football participation). (But) it just baffles me how we're still so far ahead yet so far behind too," Turnbull said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

title: Sustainable timber certification under fire
text:
When conservationist Stuart Inchley hosts people at his Turtons Creek property, he always invites them to his tree house.

Four metres in the air overlooking native temperate rainforest, the tree house thrusts visitors into the canopy of the South Gippsland bushland, and even accommodates a hammock for sleeping amongst the trees.

Stuart Inchley's rainforest treehouse at his Turtons Creek property, South Gippsland. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery )

"We've had nearly 400 people come out to visit," Mr Inchley said.

"You get down here, and it's like you step back to Gondwana."

But he fears his tree house and its lush surrounds could be at risk, due to auditing errors with a sustainable timber plantation next door.

Mr Inchley's property abuts the Hancock Victorian Plantation's (HVP) Fellas Coupe site near Foster in South Gippsland.

He said he believes the errors mean the company has logged near areas that should have been identified as endangered rainforest, with the flow-on effect potentially damaging wider ecosystems and affecting wildlife corridors on his property.

HVP holds Sustainable Forestry Certification, a voluntary scheme that can be used on any timber-related products from construction timber to tissues and paper.

The certification aims to balance the logging of native timbers with protecting the areas where they grow, and minimising the damage to the environment.

But documents point to auditing issues, while academic research suggests timber certification has damaged native forest Australia-wide, sparking calls to reform the sector.

Step back to Gondwana

When Mr Inchley's wife Victoria found a rare tree fern in a gully on their property, it proved to be an important environmental discovery.

A subsequent survey found about 130 of the endangered ferns, adding to the limited numbers of the plant statewide.

Stuart Inchley is the steward of a patch of temperate rainforest at Turtons Creek, in South Gippsland. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery )

"And that was around the same time they started logging next door," Mr Inchley said.

HVP is one of Australia's largest private timber plantation companies and is accredited for sustainable forest management by the two independent bodies in Australia responsible for handing out those certifications — the Forest Stewardship Council and Responsible Wood.

But a recent assessment by independent body Assurance Services International (ASI), which oversees certification compliance, revealed auditing errors in the Fellas Coupe plantation.

One major issue was using what ASI says are inappropriate techniques for identifying particularly fragile eco-systems within the wider environment.

The ASI report found HVP "did not identify existing rainforest and told ASI that rainforest was not found in several coupes where qualified ecologists, including the ASI technical expert, have identified rainforest as being present".

Mr Inchley said the non-compliance could result in damage to endangered species, such as the slender tree fern, along with wildlife living in the habitat.

"I would love to see a balanced mosaic of conservation, farming, forestry, all working together with small communities in getting that balance," Mr Inchley said.

"But we haven't got that balance right."

Change needed

But researchers say the entire sustainable forest management certification system needs an overhaul.

In a recent academic report, Australian National University professor David Lindenmayer wrote Australia's forest biodiversity was at risk from a range of threats, including gaps in protected areas that face industrial logging.

Professor David Lindenmayer. (Supplied: David Lindenmayer)

"We found that a large proportion of logging has occurred within optimal areas for the protection of forest and woodland-dependent species of national environmental significance," the report said.

"Our analyses indicate that logging operations are compromising Australia's intention to meet its conservation goals.

"Our findings highlight the need for urgent reform in Australia's certification schemes and the importance of a significant expansion in protected areas."

Industry response

HVP said audits were used to strengthen "how we operate to maintain high standards across the estate".

However, the company did not respond to direct questions about how it was addressing the auditing errors.

HVP said threatened species are protected in line with certification bodies, "and we continue to strengthen our impact assessments, particularly in the Strzelecki Ranges".

Slender tree ferns at Fellas Coupe in South Gippsland. (Supplied: Stuart Inchley )

The company is the custodian of large sections of forested crown land under an agreement made with the state government in the 1990s.

HVP said that as part of its management it was regenerating 19 hectares of eucalypt plantation at Fellas Track, has set aside 23,000 hectares of forest in the Strzelecki region for permanent protection, and restored more than 1,200 hectares of harvested plantation to native forest.

Matt de Jongh, director of industry group Forestry Australia, said he stood by the accreditation systems in Australia, which were constantly reviewed to reflect contemporary science.

Mr de Jongh said certification was beneficial for the environment, "not only biodiversity-wise, but also from a climate mitigation perspective".

"When consumers purchase a product, whether it be a piece of timber, or paper, or cardboard packaging … they can be assured that no deforestation has taken place, and it's also followed an ethical and responsible supply chain as well," he said.

A broken promise

Lisa Barrand owns property at Turtons Creek and is a member of conservation group Gippsland Forest Guardians.

Gippsland Forest Guardians has called for reparations to be made to any damaged forest in HVP's plantations.

"All of these undetected non-conformances occurred while HVP were cutting down and selling the timber from these sites at a premium FSC certified price," Ms Barrand said.

She said people should care about what was happening in a remote pocket of rainforest in Gippsland, regardless of where they lived.

Major supermarkets and superannuation funds invest in sustainable timber, with the sector worth millions, which Ms Barrand said made transparency in the system imperative for shareholders and citizens alike.

Lisa Barrand has concerns that environmental obligations are not being met at a neighbouring plantation. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery )

"Companies and governments make promises to look after land like this," she said.

"We relax a little bit — we've entrusted an organisation or government to do the right thing and we can say someone's looking after it on our behalf.

"[But] that promise has been broken.

"And we should care about that, and be taking action to actually hold those companies and the government to account."

title: The signs your child might have a developmental delay
text:
One of the biggest changes to disability support in a generation is the new Thriving Kids program.

The scheme, which is expected to start rolling out in mid-2026, is pitched as an alternative to the NDIS for kids with what the government calls "mild to moderate" autism or developmental delay.

But what is a developmental delay, how can you tell if your child has one, and what can you do about it?

What is developmental delay?

Developmental delay is an umbrella term for when a child doesn't hit milestones at expected age levels.

It refers to a lag in play and social skills, motor skills, problem-solving skills, self-regulation skills, and communication skills, according to Gehan Roberts, a paediatrician at the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne.

Gehan Roberts says when children don't reach milestones at the expected age levels this is referred to as a developmental delay. (Supplied: The Royal Children’s Hospital)

He says communication is the most common area where delays tend to occur.

"We expect children to have a few single words by their first birthday, or to be combining words into short two-word phrases by their second birthday," Dr Roberts says.

" And when children don't achieve those … then the term 'developmental delay' is used as a way of flagging that child as somebody who needs some more enhanced monitoring, and potentially, intervention. "

What are the signs?

Melbourne mum Lusia Ford has three sons, including two who are autistic and have developmental disorders.

Her youngest, Fletcher, now 11, was diagnosed with dysgraphia after Ms Ford noticed he was finding it difficult to write his name legibly.

"It was really evident during COVID because he was homeschooling and I was really noticing that he was struggling to write," Ms Ford says.

Luisa Ford's youngest son Fletcher struggled with his writing. (ABC News: Patrick Stone)

That came after her middle child's diagnosis of dyspraxia (also known as developmental coordination disorder), a neurological condition affecting motor coordination.

"We were noticing that he was falling over a lot … and wasn't getting his hands down in time to protect his head or his face," Ms Ford says.

What should you do if you notice a potential delay?

Dr Roberts says a good place to start is the primary care system.

"Maternal and child health nurses, GPs, both of these workforces are able to respond to parents' concerns … to try and pin down what areas of the child's development need to be monitored more closely," he says.

He says the decision from there could range from "watch and wait", to referring the child to specialists for targeted interventions, or upskilling parents.

The latter has been big for Ms Ford and her family.

Do you have a story to share? Email Specialist.Team@abc.net.au

While paediatricians, occupational therapists, speech therapists and other specialists have helped her boys see improvements, they've also been crucial in supporting her.

" Our therapists have really [helped me] understand what I can do when they're not in therapy sessions, what I can do for the other seven days we are at home to really cement some of those new ways of doing things. "

How will developmental delay fit into Thriving Kids?

At the moment, therapies can be accessed through state government-funded community health centres or through private therapists, which many parents pay for using NDIS funds.

However, the government says lumping the families of kids with developmental delays with large NDIS packages and being left to work out how to spend it doesn't always lead to the best outcomes.

Minister Mark Butler has also said some children with development delays have been "overserviced" by the scheme.

With Thriving Kids, the government wants to scale up the ability of existing community services — such as state-run child health services, GPs, and educational settings — to support families.

The government is also looking at creating a new Medicare item for bulk-billed three-year-old health checks to pick up any developmental concerns.

What could Thriving Kids look like? Despite the government wanting its Thriving Kids program for children with "mild to moderate" developmental delay and autism to start next year, the system is yet to be designed.

But exactly how things will shape up once Thriving Kids begins is unclear — something causing concern in the disability sector and among families.

While there's lots of water left to go under the bridge for Thriving Kids, Dr Roberts says good, evidence-based information sources will continue to be available.

"We have to remind ourselves that there was a landscape before NDIS and it was around a lot of systems that are still active," he says.

"But the current concern is that the NDIS is seen by many people as … the only lifeboat in the ocean … so we're very hopeful that Thriving Kids will change some of the options available for families."

Can every developmental delay be 'fixed'?

Dr Roberts says the majority of kids with early developmental delays improve with intervention.

"Fifteen to 20 per cent of kids will experience some form of developmental delay [and] we go into this space with the expectation that if we identify the things that need to be changed and provide the necessary inputs, the child will make progress," he says.

"But for those who don't improve as expected … thinking about whether they could have an underlying neurodevelopmental disorder, for example, autism spectrum disorder or intellectual disability, is important."

The government says kids with "significant and permanent disability" will continue to have access to the NDIS.

What else should you know?

Ms Ford says there are several things she wishes she knew when starting out on her family's journey.

"Progress looks different for every child. There's probably a lot of mums out there like I was picking up a lot of parenting books, reading websites and listening to podcasts and thinking it was linear. It's not and it's going to be a different journey for every kid and that's okay," she says.

" And milestones are just markers, they're not measures of value. "

Luisa Ford says both her sons have seen improvements since their diagnoses. (ABC News: Patrick Stone)

Dr Roberts says if you feel something isn't right or you don't get the answers you want, trust your gut and seek more information from evidence-based sources.

"Parents are the experts in their own children," he says.

"It's not about all the hours of therapy or taking the child to all of these different kind of clinicians. It's about parents understanding their child, what are their strengths, what are the areas that need to be developed further and how do we really reinforce the parent or the carer's role in providing that input in everyday interaction."

title: Woman who paid back debt faces community housing eviction amid 'other factors'
text:
Sometime tomorrow, Nicola Torres is expecting to be evicted from the home she and her two children have lived in for the last few years.

"Being in the property, I've had a goal of home ownership. That's far-fetched now," she said.

" We've got nowhere to go and I feel like I'm at risk of losing everything. "

Ms Torres said she understood the eviction was because she was unable to pay her rent for a period and fell behind, but later paid it back.

Ms Torres holds a letter from Foundation Housing. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

That hasn't changed the decision to evict the trio, and their dogs.

What makes Ms Torres’s story interesting is that the decision hasn't been made by a private landlord.

It was made by a community housing provider — an organisation which owns and manages the property on behalf of the state government.

The provider, Foundation Housing, said there was more to the story, but privacy restrictions stopped it from saying what those were.

Thousands of properties

Ms Torres’s home at Forrestfield — in Perth's south-east — is one of around 7,500 community housing properties in WA, which help the government expand its social housing pool.

In addition to taking government money, community housing providers can use money from superannuation funds and other investors to help build more social housing.

Ms Torres was living in one of 7,500 community housing properties in Perth. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

Some also run larger sites — like apartment buildings — which can have staff onsite to provide direct, responsive help to tenants to deal with any issues quickly.

When the system works well, it can provide support to people who need extra help staying in their homes while they balance other challenges in their lives.

But there remains concerns about those falling through the cracks.

Eviction rate woes

The vast majority of people in community housing or traditional government-managed public housing have unremarkable experiences and benefit from the safety net those homes provide.

Homeless battle poor sleep, bad diets and stress Western Australian research is showing a strong link between homelessness and poor health, with life expectancy more than 30 years lower for people without secure housing.

However, for somewhere around 200 people a year, the relationship between landlord and tenant breaks down and they are evicted following a court order.

What concerns some is that the rate of evictions from community housing is around five times higher than from government-run public housing, according to the last two years where data is available.

"There's been some great initiatives and there are a lot of good people, great people, working in the [community housing] sector," Greens housing spokesperson Tim Clifford said.

Mr Clifford believes the stakes are high in the sector as housing is fundamental to a person's life. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

" But there has been concern raised about the eviction rates in the sector, and also the transparency and accountability with the sector. "

Tenancy terminated

Ms Torres will tomorrow be added to that tally of evictions from community housing following a court order.

Her home's rent had been set according to her income. But she said it was never adjusted after a period where she couldn't work because of mental ill health and caring responsibilities.

She said she mentioned those challenges to a Foundation Housing worker who visited her after a difficult period.

"And then the next thing I heard from Foundation Housing … my tenancy was being terminated," she recalled.

Ms Torres says she paid the arrears after the housing provider was granted a court order. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

From that point, Ms Torres said she struggled to communicate with the organisation, saying one staff member requested all communications via email.

"I was just wanting to be able to have a conversation about what was going on and why," she said.

The eviction process continued. Foundation Housing was granted a court order in October to evict the family, after which Ms Torres said she repaid the arrears.

Community housing is one of many approaches to Australia's real estate crisis. (ABC News: Gian De Poloni)

"That was the only time I managed to hear from Foundation Housing," she said.

" They were texting me, calling me, emailing me, wanting to speak with me to return my money in full. "

While Foundation Housing said it was focused on finding ways to sustain tenancies where possible, Ms Torres said that was not her experience, saying she received little support from the organisation.

'Other factors' at play

A Foundation Housing spokesperson said there were "other contributing factors in addition to rent arrears" but said it could not say what those problems were.

"Where an individual tenant's income changes … the tenant is obliged to advise Foundation Housing," they said.

Mr Smith says the organisation prioritises early intervention. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

The organisation's CEO, Chris Smith, told the ABC his organisation "prioritises early intervention, clear communication, support referrals and reasonable opportunities for tenants to resolve issues".

"Foundation Housing made multiple attempts to engage with the tenant, address rent arrears, and explore options to stabilise the tenancy, including opportunities for financial review and support," he said in a statement.

Hundreds still sleeping rough as WA falls short of ambitious target Social services want the WA government to use its budget surplus to invest in breaking people out of the cycle of homelessness, after it failed to achieve its goal of ending rough sleeping.

"Unfortunately, despite these efforts, the matter ultimately progressed through the formal court process."

Asked why Foundation Housing was evicting Ms Torres despite her repaying her debt, Mr Smith said the organisation was obliged to act in accordance with court decisions.

"More broadly, Foundation Housing's mission is to provide safe, secure and sustainable housing for people on low incomes and those experiencing vulnerability, while also ensuring the safety of our staff, contractors and the wider community, and the fair allocation of limited social housing resources," he said.

Question over decision-making process

Mr Clifford said the significant difference in eviction rates between public and community housing raised questions about how those decisions were being made.

"The essential question that should be asked is, is the government doing enough, are they providing enough funding," he said, pointing especially to support services provided to tenants.

Mr Carey says millions of dollars has been invested to boost housing stock. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

Housing and Works Minister, John Carey, said there had been "significant investments" to grow community housing, including $6 million to "boost the capacity and capability of the sector".

He said providers must comply with the National Regulatory Code which requires them to be "fair, transparent and responsive" in addition to complying with the law and government policies, with evictions only ever a "last resort".

Downsizers hampered by shortage of small homes While many older people say they are keen to downsize their home, the complex reality of doing so leaves many stuck in the family castle.

"Where concerns arise that a registered [community housing provider] is not adequately supporting tenants or is using eviction prematurely, complaints can be submitted to the Community Housing Registration Office (CHRO) for investigation," Mr Carey said.

"The CHRO can investigate potential breaches … and issue findings of non-compliance to a registered CHP, along with recommendations.

"Failure to address recommendations and continued non-compliance could result in escalated enforcement action, including potential deregistration."

Decisions magnified

The CHRO's website says no enforcement action has been taken against any community housing provider.

And it's important to point out these issues — even though more common in the community housing sector — account for only a small fraction of the tens of thousands of successful tenancies maintained across the state.

Despite the evictions, tens of thousands of tenancies for WA's most vulnerable remain successful. (ABC News: Gian De Poloni)

But in the midst of a housing crisis pushing more people to the edge and leaving community housing providers with limited options, the effects of each decision are magnified.

That's especially true for people already battling any number of other challenges, often without the support they need to get through them.

title: 'It sucks': Ex-Test leggie urges Aussies to back spin after Murphy omission
text:
Leg spinner Mitchell Swepson says "it sucks" seeing Australian selectors overlook frontline tweakers, urging officials and curators to buck the growing trend of producing pitches that heavily favour seam bowlers.

Australia is without a specialist spinner at the SCG for the first time in 138 years after Nathan Lyon's injury replacement Todd Murphy was left out of the Ashes series finale.

It is the fourth time Australia has opted against playing a spinner in their past six Tests.

In stark contrast, Australia used a spinner in all but one of its 120 Tests between the start of April 2013 and the end of June 2025.

"I won't be careful — it sucks," said Swepson, who made four Test appearances for Australia in 2022.

"I'm obviously biased, but I think we've seen it coming in Sheffield Shield cricket.

"We see less and less spin bowlers coming into the game, particularly in certain parts of the country, and that's what we're now seeing a little bit with the Test arena.

"We're seeing greener wickets and seam being the main source of wickets, and it's such a shame because there's definitely a spot for spin bowling in Test cricket."

Swepson said he suspected cricket officials were more concerned about avoiding pitches that flatten out and produce draws, rather than decks that lead to matches finishing early.

But that call comes as Cricket Australia (CA) considers stepping in to ensure pitches are produced for Tests to last into days four and five, after losing an estimated $15 million through shortened Ashes contests this summer.

Mitch Swepson has played four Tests for Australia. (Getty Images: Jason McCawley)

"Talking to older guys in Shield cricket … they talk about batting for two days on an absolute road and then all of sudden chunks are coming out of the wicket," Swepson said.

"I couldn't tell you the last time I played a Shield game like that.

"It's a real shame and I'd love to see it come back that way, but somewhere in the country has to be prepared to do that and be prepared to make those sort of wickets.

"I don't know who's going to do that first or whether it's a CA thing or what it is, but it would be great to see that happen again."

England was 3-211 at stumps on day one at the SCG amid criticism of Australia's decision not to pick a specialist spinner.

Australia assistant coach Dan Vettori, who played 113 Tests for New Zealand as a spinner, defended the decision to leave Murphy out in Sydney.

Vettori said Murphy's omission was based on Australia believing the SCG was a seam-friendly pitch.

"The bowler [Murphy] that presented in these last two games has been the bowler we first saw in India when he first came on the scene," Vettori said after stumps on day one.

"I think he's ready. He's bowling exceptionally well, once again. It's just tough to see him getting into the game when these conditions tend to suit seam bowling."

AAP

title: Japan's sacred 'forbidden island' completely off limits to women
text:
Bursting with colour, edged with mountainous cliffs and nestled between Japan and the Korean Peninsula sits a sacred, World Heritage-listed "forbidden" island.

Okinoshima island is shrouded in taboos, rich in ancient treasures and boasts thousands of years of history.

It's also completely off-limits to women.

Deeply rooted in Shinto religious tradition, the 97-hectare island, about 60 kilometres from Munakata city in Kyushu's Fukuoka Prefecture, is one of the few locations in Japan that has been largely untouched since the ninth century.

Men visiting Okinoshima before 2017 were required to purify themselves with sea water. (AFP: Jiji Press)

Until 2017, only 200 men were permitted to visit the island for a single day each year for its annual On-Site Grand Festival.

The men had to observe strict religious prohibitions, said Miki Okadera of the secretariat of the Council for the Preservation and Utilisation of the Sacred Island of Okinoshima and Associated Sites in the Munakata Region.

She said they had to follow purification rituals performed naked in the waters surrounding the island upon landing, abide by the "Oiwazu-sama" taboo that forbids disclosing anything seen or heard on the island, and could not remove a single tree, blade of grass, or stone from the island.

Professor Simon Kaner is a member of the international expert panel that assessed Okinoshima's bid for World Heritage listing in 2017, and is one of only a handful of foreigners invited to visit the island.

"The island is surrounded by taboos," said Professor Kaner, who is the head of archaeology and heritage at the Sainsbury Institute for the Study of Japanese Arts and Cultures.

" I'm not supposed to tell anybody about what I saw and I wasn't allowed to take anything from the island. "

Out of respect, many even refrain from uttering the name Okinoshima, instead referring to the "island whose name cannot be spoken", the island's committee website states.

The island is home to a collection of 80,000 votive offerings — national treasures, or artefacts — which were deposited there by envoys going back and forth between Japan and the East Asian mainland between the fourth and ninth centuries.

Sacred rituals using these offerings were conducted on the island to pray for the protection of the ships and the safety of the sailors.

"Okinoshima is a microcosm of many of the mysteries which surround Japan's ancient past and a treasure house which casts light on Japan's interactions with the ancient world," Professor Kaner said.

A pure gold ring believed to come from the royal tomb in Gyeongju on the Korean Peninsula is one of the tens of thousands of "national treasures" extracted from Okinoshima island. (Supplied: Sacred Island of Okinoshima and Associated Sites in the Munakata Region digital archive)

Since 2017, the island has been occupied by a rotation of two dozen Shinto priests from the Munakata Taisha Shinto shrine.

Public access without permission is a criminal offence.

Only one priest occupies the island at any given time, working a 10-day roster rotation undertaking rituals and general maintenance.

"The island remains an object of religious devotion to this day," Ms Okadera said.

Professor Kaner said one of those rituals was intended to venerate the spirits which they believe inhabit the island — the three female deities [or goddesses] of the Munakata Taisha shrines.

They believe the spirits have control over the straits between Kyushu and the Korean Peninsula, he said.

A Shinto priest holds a ritual ceremony at the Okitsugu shrine of the Munakata Taisha on Okinoshima island. (AFP: STR/Jiji Press)

"Whether you believe in those abilities or not, I can say it's a place that has a very special atmosphere," he said.

It is the gender of these spirits, along with other beliefs about menstruation and impure blood, which are responsible for the island's exclusivity.

Japan's gender taboo rooted in religion

Okinoshima's exclusion of women comes from both the Shinto and Buddhist religious traditions, according to Kaori Okano, a professor of Asian studies and Japanese at La Trobe University.

One of the Shinto beliefs is that the menstrual blood of a woman is "impure".

"Menstruation and childbirth produce a lot of blood, and the blood itself is considered as somehow unclean and impure," she said.

A Shinto ritual is held at Munakata Grand Shrine's Okitsumiya on Okinoshima Island. (AFP: Ichiro Ohara Yomiuri/The Yomiuri Shimbun)

But it wasn't until Buddhism came to Japan in the mid-sixth century that women were banned from Okinoshima completely.

"Buddhism brought in this more permanent view of women's inferiority and it made this idea [of impure blood] stronger," Professor Okano said.

Another important Shinto belief was that divine spirits — usually those of a goddess — reside in natural elements like mountains and seas, and can become "jealous" of other women and "upset" in their presence.

"Nature worship believes there is a god in the mountain, a god in the sea … so there is a god in Okinoshima island," Professor Okano said.

"And if there are female gods there, human beings didn't want to upset the female god by involving women there."

Okitsumiya Yohaisho, located on the nearby Oshima Island, is a place where people worship Okinoshima from afar. (Supplied: Sacred Island of Okinoshima and Associated Sites in the Munakata Region digital archive)

Okinoshima is not the only sacred place in Japan to ban women.

Gender exclusivity is woven throughout traditional Japanese history, with women banned from many mountains, temples, places of worship and Shinto sacred sites for thousands of years.

These exclusions continue to have ramifications in contemporary society.

Could Japan's first PM challenge gender beliefs?

Japan this year ranked 118th out of 148 countries in the Global Gender Gap Index (GGGI), the lowest among G7 nations.

Professor Okano said that while Japan scored highly for women's education and health, it ranked poorly in politics, employment and the economy.

Japan may have its first female PM, but some say it is not a win for women In the world of male-dominated politics, Sanae Takaichi has broken through an incredibly tough glass ceiling.

"In comparison to other first-world countries, the women's status is low, and there's definitely a gender division in terms of family responsibility and employment," Professor Okano said.

In October, the country elected its first female prime minister, Sanae Takaichi.

However, not long after she took the top job, she was forced to let a male advisor step into the ring to present the Prime Minister's Cup to the winner of an annual sumo tournament due to the sport's longstanding ties to Shinto tradition.

Professor Okano said she did not believe Ms Takaichi would spend her reign directly challenging gender divisions in the country.

Takahiro Inoue, an advisor to Sanae Takaichi, presented the Prime Minister's Cup at Fukuoka Kokusai Center in Fukuoka. (Reuters: Kyodo)

"She's a right-wing thinker in terms of defence and economy and she's against the idea of allowing married women to maintain their maiden names. So I don't think she is progressive," she said.

"However, the fact that she, a woman, became prime minister — you can't become something that you have never seen."

Nostalgia of tradition and gender discrimination

Professor Okano questioned whether the World Heritage Committee should have granted Okinoshima its listing while women were still banned.

"Having Okinoshima as World Heritage in a way legitimatises this gender-specific practice," she said.

She said bans on women visiting many mountains in Japan for the same religious beliefs had been scrapped and people had still been able to continue practising their religion.

"Even though from a feminist perspective this is a gender discrimination — kind of systemic exclusion of a woman from visiting some places or participating in certain activities — some people may see this as a nostalgic tradition," she said.

"And sometimes people — not everyone — tend to romanticise tradition.

"But in order to emphasise nostalgia for the tradition, you don't have to practice it today."

Okinoshima is visible from the summit of Mount Mitake on the main island of Kyushu. (Supplied: Imaki Hidekazu, World Heritage Promotion Committee)

She said the topic was heavily debated when Munakata City was nominating Okinoshima for World Heritage.

Professor Kaner said the prohibition on women visiting the island had been "one of the really problematic aspects of the World Heritage inscription".

"I would never say that the example of Okinoshima should be used in order to encourage more places to exclude anybody of any gender or any religious bent or anything at all," he said.

Preserving Okinoshima's sanctity

A UNESCO spokesperson told the ABC that the island and its surrounding sites were granted World Heritage status on the basis of their Outstanding Universal Value (OUV).

Sue ware long-necked jars were also unearthed on Okinoshima from the seventh to eighth century. (Supplied: Sacred Island of Okinoshima and Associated Sites in the Munakata Region digital archive)

According to the World Heritage listing, these include the cultural tradition of worshipping a sacred island and important exchanges amongst the different polities in East Asia between the fourth and the ninth centuries.

"In the island's nomination dossier, the longstanding customs and ritual practices associated with the property were described," the spokesperson said.

"However, the gender concerns were not raised with regard to its OUV, integrity, authenticity, protection and management.

"UNESCO does not intervene in the social, cultural, or religious practices that fall within the domestic affairs of its state's parties.

" Regulations concerning access to sacred sites are addressed within national legal and cultural frameworks and fall under the responsibility of the state party concerned. "

Okinoshima is not the only World Heritage-listed site with taboos. (AFP: Masanobu Nakatsukasa/The Yomiuri Shimbun)

The UNESCO spokesperson said there were other World Heritage sites where certain individuals may be prohibited from entering certain areas or participating in rituals, including Mount Athos in Greece, Sacred Mijikenda Kaya Forests in Kenya, Lake Baikal in Russia, and Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park in Australia.

"It is noteworthy that UNESCO continues to promote gender equality as a global priority, while respecting the framework of the World Heritage Convention and cultural diversity," the spokesperson said.

Professor Kaner said the gender exclusion was "an issue that's recognised by the shrine authorities, and that's why they decided to no longer allow the larger groups of men [who visited annually] to go there anymore".

Crupper ornaments from the sixth to seventh century, likely from a horse saddle, found on Okinoshima. (Supplied: Sacred Island of Okinoshima and Associated Sites in the Munakata Region digital archive)

"Many of [these objects that] have now been designated as national treasures have tremendous value for both Japan and for people all around the world in understanding the contribution that Japan has made to world history," he said.

"In the same way that a place like Uluru now has restricted access, these kinds of restrictions — ideally not gender-based ones — are one way to not control, but maintain the original state of some of these sites which are perhaps more fragile in nature than others."

title: Ashes LIVE: Root notches century but Smith’s brainless shot gives Aussies hope
text:
It’s here. The new ball. A new hope for Australia.

Mitchell Starc has it. Can he now make that new ball hit the stumps, or the batter’s pad in front of the stumps, or the batter’s bat, in a way that makes it go high enough in the air for an Australian player to catch it before it lands on the ground?

Australia need him to do at least one of those things, preferably involving Joe Root, very soon. And then to do it three more times. Because England have a big score already, and this is dangerous territory for the home side.

Well, he couldn’t do it in that first over of this spell. But he came frightfully close with a ripping yorker that Root managed to dig out from under him at the last moment … and then Root squeezes a shot wide of gully for a four with the last ball of the over, which looked, until then, certain to finish as a maiden.

Instead, England go past 350. Over to you at the other end, Scotty Boland.

England 6-351 (Root 143*, Jacks 13*)

title: ‘We have to find a place to flatten out’: Designs revealed for Brisbane Olympic stadium
text:
The design of the centrepiece stadium for Brisbane 2032 has been revealed, with its location all but confirmed at the centre of the 64-hectare Victoria Park.

Concept renders of the 63,000-seat venue were released by the Queensland government on Monday, the vision of Australian architecture firms COX and Hassell, along with Japan-based Azusa Sekkei.

The four shortlisted architectural teams had different options, Games Independent Infrastructure and Coordination Authority chief executive Simon Crooks said, but generally “most of them landed on the same area” within the park.

“When I first started my role, I thought there was 200,000 cubic metres of earthworks,” he said.

Gelato after dinner is a Carlton ritual, but Beku offers even more choice, with flavours such as durian, kalamansi and Milo inside silver pozzetti. The gelato shop distils ideas from South-East Asia to create smooth, creamy treats in cups and cones.

Must order: Pandan rice pudding is a winner.

title: Energy companies boost ASX despite Venezuela strikes
text:
The Australian sharemarket has risen at the open despite dramatic events in Venezuela over the weekend, with energy companies helping fuel the local bourse despite a decline in oil prices due to the crisis.

The ASX gained 0.21 per cent on Monday, or 18 points, to 8746 just after market open. The sharemarket clawed back early losses in its first trading session of 2026 on Friday, and Monday marks the first full trading week of the new year.

The ASX rose in early trade after clawing back early losses to close ahead last week. Credit: Wayne Taylor

Six out of 11 sectors were in the green, but energy stocks were the only sector to report a notable gain, with Woodside up 0.6 per cent and Santos gaining 1.1 per cent. This was despite Brent crude oil prices falling 0.3 per cent to $US60.57 a barrel as jittery markets reacted to the US-led strikes.

Non-oil energy companies have also benefited, with uranium miner Paladin gaining 10 per cent while Silex and NexGen also up a similar amount.

title: An Australian is captain of the world’s smartest rugby team
text:
He said it was “a long shot, a stab in the dark” to then apply for entry into Oxford. In addition to his outstanding tertiary qualifications, written submissions, and references, he was required to undergo an interview process. He was invited to spend a year studying for a Master’s degree and has stayed for two more years to complete a PhD. Oxford University skipper Jack Hamilton, an Australian studying neuroscience. Meanwhile, in between countless hours spent in lecture rooms, Hamilton found time to establish himself in Oxford’s rugby team. This season, the former Newcastle Wanderers junior, who also played for Sydney University, has been honoured with the captaincy. He is the second Novocastrian to lead the Blues, following in the footsteps of Dave Lubans, now a professor at Newcastle University.

As well as skippering Oxford next month in their annual Varsity clash with Cambridge – a rivalry that dates back to 1872 – Hamilton is also at the helm of their first tour of Australia in 30 years. They play Newcastle Uni on January 6 and Sydney Uni on January 9. The latter will be played for the Ian Tucker Challenge Cup, named after a 23-year-old Australian who died while playing for Oxford in 1996. The Oxford University team have been staying at St Andrew’s College on the Sydney University campus. Credit: Sitthixay Ditthavong Both of their opponents will undoubtedly feature their fair share of highly educated players, but Oxford is on another level. “In my team, we’ve got five or six guys who are studying at Oxford medical school,” Hamilton explained.

“We’ve got guys doing PhDs in physics, PhDs in cardio-respiratory science, guys that are doing high-level mathematics, poetry, English, biochemistry. “It’s a real mix. They’re all up-and-coming leaders in their fields, and they all study bloody hard. Oxford University will play two matches on their tour of Australia. “All of our training sessions are outside of nine to five because the guys are in class all day, every day. We’re in the gym at 6.30am so that everyone can be finished, showered and ready to go for the first lectures at 9am.” Coach and general manager Ian Kench, who played for Oxford in 2008-09, laughed when he said: “Can you imagine coaching them?

“My first session here, I had to ask them to stop asking questions until the end of the session. “They’re opinionated, which is good, but it certainly makes it challenging as a coach. They’re good men, but they have curious brains, and they want to know the rationale behind everything. They don’t just do what they’re told, like other teams I’ve coached. “But it’s good. It’s made me a better coach.” During their tour Down Under, part of Oxford’s mission will be to spread the gospel and roll out the welcome mat. The university has a proud tradition of Australian alumni in its rugby team, including Wallabies Brett Robinson, Joe Roff and, most recently, Tom Robertson.

“This year I’m the only Aussie in the team, but in my first year we had four or five, including Tom Robertson, who’s obviously played for the Wallabies,” Hamilton said. “We’re looking for that niche of players who are capable rugby players, but intelligent and have academic desires to push on because they’re the ones who are going to have good academic transcripts and be eligible. “There’s a long, long history of Australia players coming to Oxford and playing, and even captaining them. “Australia is a really important resource for Oxford rugby and has a really strong history. So we’re definitely out here looking to recruit … we’re trying to get the word out that it is viable and it is an option. “I think a lot of people aren’t aware.”

Loading Hamilton said there were multiple scholarships available for Australians who qualify to study at Oxford. But given the 900-year-old university unashamedly declares only the “best and brightest” are invited to enter its halls, applicants will be judged on their scholastic CV, rather than their scrummaging technique or sidestepping. “There are no exceptions,” Kench said. “We’ve had internationals with 50-plus Test caps to their name apply to get into the university, but we’ve had to tell them that their academic CV is not at the calibre it needs to be.

title: ‘It’s just insane’: Doctors, lawyers back green slips for e-bikes
text:
Owners of e-bikes could soon be forced to be covered by the same green slip insurance requirements as those applying to other road vehicles following a spate of serious collisions involving electric-powered devices on the state’s roads.

Doctors and legal experts are leading a push for the NSW government to overhaul the state’s compulsory insurance requirements in a move to address a “compensation gap” leaving uninsured e-bike riders and victims of collisions financially vulnerable.

The number of privately owned electric powered bikes and scooters has surged in NSW. Credit: Max Mason-Hubers

The Australian Lawyers Alliance and NSW Bar Association, which represents more than 2400 barristers across the state, have emerged as the strongest voices for change – urging the NSW government to introduce new regulations requiring privately owned devices to be registered and covered by compulsory third-party insurance.

And there are signs the NSW government is listening with Transport Minister John Graham revealing the government has tasked NSW Treasury with “exploring insurance options” for privately owned e-bikes with public consultation on a potential scheme expected to commence this year.

title: ‘We’re in the entertainment business’: CA boss frustrated by cricket’s bad light rules
text:
A frustrated Cricket Australia chief executive Todd Greenberg has vowed to up the ante at ICC level for a change to cricket’s bad light conventions after losing a third of the Sydney Test’s opening day to inclement weather.

An SCG crowd of 49,574 – the largest cricket attendance in Sydney for 50 years – saw day one of the New Year’s Test cut short from 2.50pm on Sunday due to a combination of bad light, rain that barely arrived and the game’s lightning protocols.

While English batsman Harry Brook said players “could hardly see the ball” as skies darkened and Australia’s Marnus Labuschagne agreed with the call to take players off, the umpires’ decision to keep play from resuming on safety grounds perplexed fans, commentators and Greenberg.

ICC rules dictate that play cannot resume until at least 30 minutes after lightning strikes around a ground, which caused an initial delay to play beginning again when skies around the SCG brightened on Sunday afternoon.

title: AI digs out more profits at mining giant BHP
text:
The world’s biggest mining company is applying artificial intelligence to conveyor belts, blasting zones, giant ore-carrying trucks, rock crushers and safety apps as it seeks to cut downtime, eliminate risks and add up to $250 million a year to its bottom line.

Perhaps the most explosive use of AI in Australian resource giant BHP’s global operations is the machine learning it has applied to blast patterns for breaking up orebodies of different densities at its cornerstone Escondida copper mine in Chile, an asset that accounts for about 5 per cent of the world’s red metal output.

AI can identify spillage from BHP’s iron ore trains, avoiding accidents. Credit: Getty

Mine operators typically drill ore samples in the bedrock they are excavating about 10 to 12 weeks before they begin digging to determine the mineralogy and grade of material they will excavate after loosening it with explosives.

Chief technical officer Johan van Jaarsveld said BHP began applying AI to historic drill data at Escondida about a year ago to help workers look for connections between “not-directly-correlated variables” that allow them to predict the orebody’s density and design a blast pattern that puts the most intense explosions against the hardest rock.
